TopicTitle: How will ATV-4 approach the ISS?

Articles.Content:
I've been following ATV-4 and the ISS on this webpage: http://www.n2yo.com/?s=39175|25544 (Thanks to nothke BTW), and I noticed that ATV-4 orbits at ~260 Km, while the ISS orbits at ~ 415 Km. That's a pretty aggressive approach, even for KSP standards.

Am I missing something?

Am I missing something?

Yup, you are missing the fact that the Earth is much more massive than Kerbin. GEO is at ~39,000 kms, while KEO is at ~2,800. As you can probably guess by now, the relative difference in orbit is much less in the case of LEO than if you had two orbits in KSP separated a couple hundred kilometers. Try more like 1/10 to scale distances (very, very roughly, as in completely inaccurate scientifically, but good rule of thumb)... this would turn out to be the rough equivalent of chasing a ~100km station form a ~80km orbit.

Rune. Not so crazy after all.
Yeah, I know Kerbin is 1/10 the size of earth... but there's still a big gap between both orbits. Even in KSP, you'd normally chase a ~100 km from a >95 km orbit.
The docking won't take place for over a week I think. It's going to slowly phase its orbit up to match that of the ISS.

(leftest white dot ATV, rightest white dot, ISS)

As you can see in this image from orbit plane normal track, it's barely a pixel xD (at least you get the sense of scale)
Docking is due on the 16th I think.
